text: this is captured bandholz with the
International Herald Tribune in Paris
I'm at the French Finance Ministry just
downstairs from the office of Christine
Lagarde who is currently preparing the
g20 the crisis summit in Washington many
people have been wondering what her role
is in this financial crisis and the
efforts to reform international
financial institutions France has been
taking a leading role in these efforts
and Christine Lagarde is no ordinary
Minister and France she's a woman she
has spent five years of her career in
the United States and she has a
background in business one of the things
that I've asked her earlier was whether
the world could really hope to achieve
anything concrete and sufficiently
momentous at the summit given that the
US administration remains in limbo and
that there's even squabbling among
Europeans about some of the details yes
I'm certain that something can be
achieved how deep how sustainable how
concrete remains to be to be
demonstrated at the time of the meeting
but I'm just back from g20 meeting only
ministers of finance and it's obvious
that there is a collective determination
to propose real changes to improve the
system to enhance the transparency to
strengthen the supervision to bring more
coordination and to fix a system that is
proven to have failed it was actually
quite interesting to see from all angles
how countries have been affected and all
have been affected another topic I
really wanted to discuss with Christine
Lagarde was the state of the economy
more generally how bad that she think
would get in Europe and in France and
what could governments do about it given
particularly stringent budgetary rules
this side of the Atlantic as far as
France is concerned for instance we
expect the year to finish the year with
one percent growth which is certainly a
lot less than we expected
and our forecast for 2009
which has i've just adjusted is reduced
to anywhere between 0.2 and point sorry
yeah point two and point five percent so
we slash growth by half essentially in
2009 and this is going to be the case or
has already been identified by countries
such as Germany Italy Spain the UK with
the dollar rising against the euro in
recent weeks I also asked her whether
this was enough of a boost for European
manufacturers and exporters to make up
for some of the decline in the domestic
demand if it will certainly help those
European companies that export and of
which the cost base is is euro
denominated and which are competing with
dollar based cost competitors will that
be enough I don't know I'm not sure that
the the euro is at the right level at
the moment my my not my fear but my
expectation is that this rise of the
dollar is not going to be forever one
thing is clear the French are very
ambitious going into this meeting but
what will actually come of it remains
highly uncertain
